title: New on DVD: 'Z for Zachariah' puts dread to good use | Entertainment News
text:
Has there ever been a better crucible for drama than an apocalypse? Whether it be a zombie apocalypse, an environmental meltdown, or nuclear war, that dread occasion can be put to great use by writers and filmmakers.
That includes Robert C. O'Brien, whose posthumously published sci-fi novel, "Z for Zachariah," has been adapted into a lean, tight, killer character study by "Compliance" director Craig Zobel. Mildly reminiscent of Cormac McCarthy's "The Road" and its 2009 film adaptation, the stirring "Z for Zachariah" is about three lonely souls trying to survive in a world devoid of other people.
Australian Margot Robbie ("Focus," "The Wolf of Wall Street") turns in a rare, incandescent performance as Ann Burden, a farm gal who believes she and her dog, Pharaoh, are the only survivors of a nuclear holocaust that has wiped out North America -- and as far as we can tell, the rest of the globe.
Filled with religious imagery and biblical references -- Ann lives quite literally in the shadow of a chapel her dad built with his own hands -- Zobel's film begins to build momentum when another person appears in the shape of the polite, if tense, John Loomis (Chiwetel Ejiofor).
But the pair, who work slowly, deliberately to become a romantic couple, soon lose exclusive use of their Eden when Caleb (Chris Pine) shows up. Oh, he's trouble. Big trouble. (www.lionsgateshop.com; $19.98 DVD; $24.99 Blu-ray; rated PG-13)
Other titles of note:
"Harry." This six-episode Kiwi import is a dark, deeply moving police procedural about a recently widowed cop (Oscar Kightley) faced with a violent series of robberies by a gang of drugged-out young men. Sam Neill costars. (www.acornonline.com; $39.99 DVD or Blu-ray; not rated)
"When Marnie Was There." This delightful animated family film is about an orphaned girl who learns to let go of her loneliness and make a friend.
(www.uphe.com; $19.99 DVD; $24.99 Blu-ray/DVD Combo; rated PG)
"DCI Banks: Season Three." Stephen Tompkinson returns as the thoughtful, lonely detective in three feature-length mysteries costarring Andrea Lowe and Caroline Catz. (www.shop.bbc.com; $34.98; not rated)
"Happyish: Season 1." Steve Coogan is brilliant as an overeducated advertising executive in Showtime's savage satire of modern life, costarring Kathryn Hahn and Bradley Whitford. (www.paramount.com/movies/home-media; $39.98; not rated)
"A Special Day." Set in 1938, this thoughtful Italian drama from 1977 stars Sophia Loren and Marcello Mastroianni as neighbors who find themselves all alone in their apartment building in Rome on the day Mussolini welcomes Hitler to town. She's a homemaker whose unfaithful, brutish husband and obnoxious kids are out celebrating the fascist leaders; he's a gay broadcaster who opposes the regime. (www.criterion.com; $29.95 DVD; $39.95 Blu-ray; not rated)
Most titles also available for digital download from major retailers.
